chapter: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following timelines would be included in the perinatal period as per WHO?

options.a: 37th week of gestation to 28 days after birth
options.b: 20th week of gestation to 7 days after birth
options.c: 28th week of gestation to 28 days after birth
options.d: 22nd week of gestation to 7 days after birth

questions.explanation:
The WHO states that the perinatal period commences at 22 completed weeks and ends at seven 
completed days after birth - 154 days. It corresponds to when the fetus weighs 500g or more. This definition is not to be confused with the period used for the calculation of the perinatal 
mortality rate (PMR). To calculate the PMR, a fetal weight above 1000 g is considered, which is 
achieved at 28 weeks of gestation. Therefore, for all statistical purposes, international 
comparisons, and calculation of perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is 
considered. 10 
Sold by @itachibot Perinatal period: from the 22nd week. Perinatal mortality rate calculation: from the 28th week. The neonatal period is defined as the first 28 days after birth. Infancy is defined as the first 
year of life. The image below shows various time periods. Only the time period for perinatal mortality and the 
perinatal period are different as shown in the image. For others, corresponding mortality rates are 
calculated using the same time periods shown.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question: Question 2: You would classify a baby as post-term if it is born after
questions.explanation:
Post-term infants are those born after 42 completed weeks of gestation, as calculated from the 
mother’s last menstrual period, regardless of weight at birth.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 3: You would classify a baby as a very low birth weight baby if the weight of the baby is found to 
be less than  
 kg.
questions.explanation:
A very low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1.5 Kg. They are often premature 
(<37 weeks of gestation). A low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <2.5 Kg. An extremely low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1 kg.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 4: Reena, a 34-year-old lady with gestation diabetes mellitus delivers an LGA baby at 37 weeks. 
What would the birth weight of this child be?
questions.explanation:
Infants with birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for their gestational age are called large 
for gestational age (LGA) babies. 11 
Sold by @itachibot Maternal diabetes and obesity are predisposing factors for LGA babies. They have a higher 
incidence of: • Birth injuries: • Brachial plexus injury • Phrenic nerve injury • Cephalohematomas • Hypoglycemia • Polycythemia • Congenital heart disease
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 5: As the intern assisting in the labor room, you are tasked with administering Vitamin K to the 
term newborns with no complications. Which of the following dose and route would you use 
for administration?
questions.explanation:
All newborn infants are to be administered vitamin K at a dose of 0.5–1 mg intramuscularly, to 
prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN). However, for newborns with vitamin K deficiency, the dose of vitamin K administered is 1–5 mg 
intravenously.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 6: A term neonate born by normal vaginal delivery is diagnosed with hypothermia. Which of the 
following is not a physiological response for heat regulation in this baby?

options.b: Breakdown of brown fat with noradrenaline secretion

questions.explanation:
Neonates do not generate heat by shivering. Heat production in neonates happens by increasing the metabolic rate and oxygen consumption 
by releasing norepinephrine, which results in non-shivering thermogenesis through 
beta-oxidation of brown fat. This sympathetic surge also causes cutaneous vasoconstriction. 12 
Sold by @itachibot Increased physical activity - crying, increased body movements, and muscular activity also 
contribute to thermogenesis. Preterm and small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants have scanty brown fat stores.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 7: You are conducting the routine newborn assessment of a 2.3 kg baby born 10 minutes back. 
You would classify the neonate as having cold stress if you notice the body temperature to be:
questions.explanation:
A temperature of 36.0 to 36.4°C categorizes a neonate as having cold stress. An infant’s normal body temperature is 36.5 to 37.5 °C. It is measured in the apex of the baby's 
axilla by holding the thermometer for at least 3 minutes. Hypothermia is an axillary temperature of <36.5 °C. • Cold stress: 36.0 to 36.4 °C • Moderate hypothermia: 32 to 35.9 °C • Severe hypothermia: <32 °C Hyperthermia is an axillary temperature of >37.5 °C.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 8: 5 
Sold by @itachibot A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth 
weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below. Which of the following 
statements about this method is false?

options.b: Safety and thermal protection is equivalent to incubators
options.c: Reduces severe morbidity in the newborns
options.d: Should be performed only by the mother

questions.explanation:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver. KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature 
newborns. It has 4 components— • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest. • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding. • Early discharge and ambulatory care. • Support for mother and family for child care. Evidence shows that- • It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality) • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding • Humanization of neonatal care • Promoted bonding between mother and child Eligibility criteria for KMC: It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can 
be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can 
vary with the birth weight of the baby. • Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC • Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation 13 
Sold by @itachibot • Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC. Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The 
hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the 
baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing 
would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea. The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 
24 hours a day. KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation. Note: Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care 
for low birthweight babies.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 9: You are the intern posted in the labor room and are tasked with calculating the gestational 
maturity of the infants delivered. As per the expanded New Ballard scoring, what will be the 
lowest and highest scores you can obtain?
questions.explanation:
The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 
weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age. An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age. Maturity Rating on the expanded New Ballard Score: Scor 
e Wee 
ks -10 
20 -5 
22 0 
24 5 
26 10 
28 15 
30 20 
32 25 
34 30 
36 35 
38 40 
40 45 
42 50 
44 14 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according 
to the expanded New Ballard score? 6 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Scarf sign is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded 
new Ballard score. Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below), • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline. • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline. Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score) include: • Posture • Square window (wrist) • Arm recoil • Popliteal angle • Scarf sign • Heel to ear Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score) include: • Skin • Lanugo • Eye/ear • Plantar crease • Breast • Genitals The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the 
newborn by scoring six criteria and thereby calculating the gestational age. It is accurate 
between 20 to 44 weeks. 15 
Sold by @itachibot The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 
weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age. 
An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age Given in the image below is the scoring system for the physical and neuromuscular criteria:
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 11: A 1.8 Kg neonate is born to a 24-year-old primigravida with no antenatal checkups. While 
calculating the physical maturity of the neonate by the new Ballard scoring, which of the 
following criteria would you not take into account?
questions.explanation:
Palmar surface is not a component of the physical criteria for maturity according to the expanded 
New Ballard score. Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score): • Skin • Lanugo • Eye/ear • Plantar crease (Not palmar surface) • Breast • Genitals
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 12: While examining a healthy term neonate, you notice that the baby passes greenish-black 
colored stools. This color is due to -
questions.explanation:
The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin. Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in 
the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill 
the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium 
is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component 16 
Sold by @itachibot responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the 
oxidation of bilirubin). Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal 
defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next few 
weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin 
oxidation system. Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools. Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question: Question 13: When does the parachute reflex disappear?

options.c: At birth and reappears at 9 months

questions.explanation:
The parachute reflex has its onset at 7–8 months of age. It is fully developed by 10-11 months of 
age and remains throughout life. It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or 
she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall. This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 14: 7 
Sold by @itachibot A 6-day old infant is being examined. While checking the reflexes, a brisk Moro's reflex is 
noted. Which of the following conditions is a likely cause for this?
questions.explanation:
A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia. In hypoglycemic babies, there is an activation of the autonomic system, which results in 
jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex. The Moro reflex is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It is 
elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall 
backward onto the examiner’s hand. An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and 
abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities is shown below 17 
Sold by @itachibot The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants. Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS • Stage III HIE • Kernicterus Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease • Fractured clavicle • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy) • Hemiparesis Brisk Moro reflex: • Neonatal hypoglycemia • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants • Stage I HIE Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine 
cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical 
influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following: • Hydranencephaly • Severe micrencephaly Moro reflex in different stages of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE): • Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk • Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete • Stage III HIE (severe): Absent Option A: In kernicterus, there is a deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and 
brain stem. Hence, the Moro reflex is absent Option C: In stage III HIE, the muscles are flaccid and the infant is comatose. Thus, the Moro 
reflex is absent. Option D: Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, the reflex is absent on the 
side of injury as the nerve supplying the muscles involved (efferent of the reflex) is affected.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 15: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On 
turning the baby's head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does 
this reflex normally disappear?
questions.explanation:
Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally. The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing 
for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated 
and flexion of the contralateral arm). 18 
Sold by @itachibot An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is 
always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 16: A first-time mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day old infant and worriedly points to the 
rash that appears as shown below. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature. On 
microscopic examination, these papular lesions on an erythematous base will reveal 8 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical complex describes a case of erythema neonatorum. Wright stained smear of the 
contents of the pustule will show an abundance of eosinophils. They are papular lesions on an erythematous base, distributed over the trunk and face 
predominantly. They are seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for up to a week, after which 
they resolve spontaneously. Neutrophils are seen in pustular melanosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care

questions.question:
Question 17: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. A lesion that was 
present since birth is noticed as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis. Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that 
appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms. These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is 
arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and 
do not rapidly change in color or size. 19 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of Newborn
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Neonatology and Routine Newborn Care
